history.content: Per Chancellor Christ's email sent out June 17: "Students will not be required to take in-person classes or be present on campus for the smaller discussion sections. Almost all academic offerings, including those with in-person instructional activities, will also be provided via a remotely delivered method." Presumably by "smaller discussion sections" and "all academic offerings," she means lab, discussion, etc. This message seems to indicate that you will not need to be present at all on campus for academic commitments, including exams and projects. I know classes with hardware lab components (e.g., EECS 16A) may send out lab kits so that students can work remotely. Students, feel free to add more info/sources if you find any. **EDIT: Please check the https://classes.berkeley.edu for the mode of instruction of different classes. Info regarding the labels can be found here: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vToHgDcRq6eYeMKjAWARjYKzEuwQbi9UFQCWIxF5Ud01WjTxNYwtxXwf1ymPbOHcYZ-6aUy6lB0vJl_/pub?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000&slide=id.g823709393f_0_0

<md>Per Chancellor Christ's email sent out June 17: "Students will not be required to take in-person classes or be present on campus for the smaller discussion sections. Almost all academic offerings, including those with in-person instructional activities, will also be provided via a remotely delivered method." Presumably by "smaller discussion sections" and "all academic offerings," she means lab, discussion, etc. This message seems to indicate that you will not need to be present at all on campus for academic commitments, including exams and projects. I know classes with hardware lab components (e.g., EECS 16A) may send out lab kits so that students can work remotely.

Students, feel free to add more info/sources if you find any.</md>

<md>Per Chancellor Christ's email sent out June 17: "Students will not be required to take in-person classes or be present on campus for the smaller discussion sections. Almost all academic offerings, including those with in-person instructional activities, will also be provided via a remotely delivered method." Presumably by "smaller discussion sections" and "all academic offerings," she means lab, discussion, etc. This message seems to indicate that you will not need to be present at all on campus for academic commitments, including exams and projects. I know classes with hardware lab components (e.g., EECS 16A) may send out lab kits so that students can work remotely.

Feel free to add more info/sources if you find any.</md>

By online I don't just mean webcasted, I mean that exams, projects etc will all be online too, so that I could go the entire semester from a different state or country. The classes I'm considering taking are CS70, CS161, CS194, and Astro C10.

I read the official announcements but most of them said 'instruction' would be delivered remotely, so I'm not sure if they just mean literal instruction as in lectures, or if they mean all aspects of the class.
history.subject: Will most large cs classes be entirely online for this fall?
